RE 
vancv : Vancouver | cabc : British Columbia | cana : Canada | namz : North America

IPD 
News]]>

PUB 
The Northern Miner Group

AN 
Document NMNR000020171212edcc0005l


HD ‘Above Ground’ Issues And Challenges Continue To Take A Toll On Canada’s Oil And Gas Industry, Investment Climate
WC 2295 words
PD 11 December 2017
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2017 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

Myriad issues from lack of egress options to regulatory hurdles continue to dampen the competitiveness of Canada’s oil and gas sector and have contributed to increasing doubt among investors as to Canada’s attractiveness, say industry experts.

Brian Schmidt, president and CEO of Tamarack Valley Energy Ltd. and a current board member of the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers (CAPP), said that in recent years the Canadian oilpatch has been delivered a series of “body blows” that have hindered the ability of companies to raise cash. Coupled with the impacts of the prolonged downturn, and it’s been tough sledding.

TD 

And Schmidt, who is chairman of CAPP’s Alberta Executive Policy Group, says current governments are doing little to help the situation.

“I think in other downturns we had help from governments that were interested in supporting our business. But we don’t have that right now. We’re pretty much on our own,” he said.

“In fact, we’ve been dealt some significant body blows with pipeline issues, increased regulations, carbon tax, minimum wage—there are a lot of things that are working against the industry right now. And I think the [cancelation of] the Energy East pipeline was a very significant event that I don’t think we understand the total impact of. It was quite negative,” Schmidt added.

“So if you’re an investor and looking at several jurisdictions, Canada is not seen as a friendly jurisdiction to do business right now because of the complications we’ve had over the years. And that contrasts to other downturns where government and industry worked together to get some of these projects underway and did what it took to get it done. I’m not seeing that right now. I think the industry is on its own and you can expect more negative pressures here.”

Gary Leach, president of the Explorers and Producers Association of Canada (EPAC) agrees, saying the “unwelcoming business and investment climate that has developed in Canada in the last few years” has taken its toll.

“It is a remarkable state of affairs for a country that relies heavily on the oil and gas industry to help balance its foreign trade, provide high paying jobs that supports equalization payments that flow from Alberta and Saskatchewan and contribute billions of dollars to federal and provincial coffers in royalties and taxes,” Leach said.

“It illustrates the inability of Canada’s political leadership at the federal and provincial levels to come together on what should be clear national interests: to make sure the nation’s non-renewable energy exports find markets at the highest world market price. It also illustrates the tremendously effective campaigns by industry opponents to influence politicians, policy and election outcomes in Canada.”

In Leach’s view, current government inaction and stance on some major energy projects runs counterintuitive to the nation’s best interests.

“I can’t think of another major energy producing nation, particularly among the world’s functioning democracies, with the potential Canada has to meet growing global demand, and yet has been so hobbled by its own governments in meeting that demand. Indeed, it’s no coincidence that a country like Canada with robust legal protection for the right to protest and with generous opportunities to intervene in the regulatory approval process, has attracted so much organized opposition,” he said.

“It’s particularly disturbing when I think we can genuinely make the case there is no oil and gas industry in the world that has a better track record when it comes to responsible energy development. Even the head of the International Energy Agency (Fatih Birol)in an October speech stated: ‘I wouldn't subscribe to the idea that we won't need oil anymore and a country like Canada, a reliable partner, a reliable producer, reliable exporter has a role to play in the global energy markets.’”

‘Above ground issues’

Peter Tertzakian, executive director of ARC Energy Research Institute, said that while increased regulations are an issue, the challenges facing the oil and gas industry run much deeper.

“It’s broader than that. There’s the issue of Indigenous people and nimbyism—it’s just all wrapped up. It’s a very broad thing. I don’t want to be quoted as saying ‘it’s because of the government, or regulation or whatever.’ It’s far beyond that,” he said.

“I think it’s a large basket. I actually categorize it as ‘above ground issues.’  The oil and gas industry has two dimensions. There’s the below ground issues of rock quality, the ability to get the stuff out of the ground, technology etcetera. So what’s happened is the below ground risks have diminished significantly over the last few years, but the above ground risks have been amplified,” Tertzakian added.

“And the above ground issues, all the way from local nimbyism to broad-based regulatory, to Indigenous issues and so on have increased. There’s no question that a lot of those above ground issues collectively are a drag on investment. It’s a very complex issue. I think we can agree that it’s the collective above ground dynamics that have hindered investment potential in Canada.”

Duane Bratt, a political science professor at Calgary’s Mount Royal University, said the federal government’s decision to reorganize the National Energy Board (NEB) has added to the challenges facing Canada’s oil and gas industry.

“I do think the reorganization and the changes to the NEB are significant. I don’t believe they’re the sole reason, or possibly even the major reason for the Energy East cancellation—I think the numbers that some economists have put forward talk about increased capacity and those sorts of things—but the fiddling with the NEB is a problem,” he said.

“Even if it wasn’t a problem with Energy East, it will be in other ones for a number of reasons. I think one of them is just the whole idea of looking at upstream and downstream effects. That becomes very complicated.”

That said, Bratt is of the belief that the overall attractiveness of Canada’s oilpatch to would-be investors remains relatively intact.

“I would think our reputation remains quite good. It’s a politically stable country. Yeah, [governments] have brought in emissions standards and carbon taxes, but those carbon taxes are consumer-wide, economy-wide,” he said.

“They’re not just focused solely on producers. I think it’s really about a cost issue. We’re a more costly economy to invest in, but a safer place to invest.”

Combating the challenges: What can the industry do better?

Bratt said that oil and gas industry efforts to obtain social license for large-scale projects and other industry-related initiatives have often fallen short.

“And what’s interesting about that is you hear critics of social license say it’s a [Prime Minister Justin] Trudeau term or an [Alberta Premier Rachel] Notley term, but it’s not. It actually came out of the Canadian mining industry and has now been applied to larger types of projects, including those in the oil and gas industry,” he said.

“If you were to read Jim Prentice’s book [Triple Crown: Winning Canada’s Energy Future] or Dennis McConaghy’s book [Dysfunction: Canada After Keystone XL], they’re quite critical of the things that industry has done. And [industry] needs to share some of the blame for some of these [unsuccessful] projects, as well,” Bratt added.

The MRU professor added that the oil and gas industry has done a relatively poor job in successfully informing the general populace of its successes and operational and environmental improvements, of which there are many.

“The thing is, a lot of the work that industry has been doing on emission reductions in the oilsands, for example, I don’t think have been particularly well known and they have trouble getting that message out because for years, executives, and some of the industry groups, were denying there was ever even a problem,” he said.

“Meanwhile, their scientists were working on ways of dropping emissions. So there’s actually I think some good news stories with some of the research and development that’s been done.”

While the Canadian oil and gas sector has done better in recent years in its attempts to get its message across, Tamarack Valley’s Schmidt says there’s still work to be done in leveling the playing field against well-funded and organized opponents.

“I think we have to realize that there’s a lot of money—and I would say out of country money—that’s coming in to campaign against the hydrocarbon industry here. And I think we’ve been far too complacent as an industry of just kind of letting that happen and then letting things go unanswered,” he said.

“So I think we need to be getting our message out there in different ways and more effectively and consistently.”

Leach believes that the industry has begun to successfully, for the most part, respond in recent years to the “shifting targets” of protesters who oppose energy infrastructure projects and the sector as a whole.

“We all remember the negative publicity around hydraulic fracturing and the industry and regulators effectively responded with science-based regulations and best practices to tackle concerns about chemical use, water consumption and induced seismicity. The target of opponents then shifted to pipelines where Canadian oil and gas producers are uniquely vulnerable due to government policy failures to ensure infrastructure was built when needed,” he said.

“Ultimately I think the necessary pipelines and facilities to accommodate Canadian production of bitumen, liquids and natural gas in the next couple of decades will be built, but unfortunately years late. For example, both the B.C. and federal governments are signaling they are motivated to ensure that another LNG project does not fail.”

Leach added that the “evolving position” of the Alberta government on energy and pipelines is “proof attitudes can change, especially when you want to get re-elected.

“And as the disastrous effects of Ontario’s green energy policies on that province’s competitive position become more apparent to voters, we should expect a similar shift among a sufficient number of Canadian voters to influence national policies too,” he said.

Not(ley) enough?

Premier Notley has embarked on a cross-Canada travelling road show to highlight the benefits of vital pipeline infrastructure, including in Vancouver and Central Canada.

But Schmidt, though appreciative, said that effort, that provincial government support, should have happened sooner.

“I think [Notley] is doing the right thing in advocating for pipelines and how important they are to Canada. I don’t think Canadians, in general, understand how significant these projects are and how it impacts our ability to pay for health care and education and some of the things we enjoy right now,” he said.

“I think there’s a serious disconnect between the public and these pipelines. So I applaud Premier Notley for getting out and getting the word out, and she’s obviously going against some of her colleagues’ policies. So I think it’s good. But I think it’s too little, too late.”

Schmidt also said the attempt of the Notley government to attain social license for pipelines and other infrastructure by invoking a carbon tax and other environmental-directed measures may have not been the best laid of plans.

“I think the idea of getting so-called social license by giving into the Green movement and carbon taxes and that sort of thing really hasn’t worked,” he said.

“I think a far better strategy would be to compare how clean and how regulated our industry is. We’re the most regulated jurisdiction in the world. And that, I think, is something we should be very proud of as Canadians.

“So not allowing our oil and gas to get to world markets just means the dirtier stuff and the stuff with conflict is going to get produced. I think that’s a better argument than carbon taxes or shutting down coal plants, that sort of thing.”

Not the end of days

Despite the many issues and challenges facing the sector, Tertzakian said the Canadian oil and gas industry still has a viable future.

“I think there’s a tendency for some to think that the whole industry is shut down. That’s far from the truth. The reality is that the industry is producing and exporting more oil and gas than ever. Consumers are consuming more than ever. Investment in certain segments of the business is showing signs of improvement,” he said.

“So in some ways, given all these above ground issues, it’s remarkable that the industry continues to operate as well as it does. I would caution, though, it’s not just because of these above ground issues. There’s disruptive changes happening in the world of capital markets—migration to ETFs, for example.”

Tertzakian said that some companies are adapting to the “new realities” better than others and those that stumble in the needed transition likely won’t fare well going forward.

“The industry is going to look different, recognizing that these above ground issues are unlikely to relent anytime soon,” he said.

“The narrative I believe is that this industry is going to be part of what I call ‘the suppliers of the future.’ Those companies that understand above ground and below ground, those are going to be the suppliers of the future—those that know how to manage and execute amidst the disruptions we’re seeing both above ground and below ground.”


CO 
capetp : Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers

IN 
i13 : Crude Oil/Natural Gas Upstream Operations | i1 : Energy

NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020171211edcb0000d


HD Sponsored Content: Accelerate Oil And Gas Transformation With Advanced Technologies
WC 1236 words
PD 8 December 2017
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2017 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

The Canadian natural resources industry is undergoing enormous change. Volatile energy prices — the reality of US 55 per barrel — reduced production reliability, uncertain market access, the government’s climate change agenda, tightening environmental policy, safety, and compliance concerns along with increasing social drivers, such as social license to operate, all have resulted in industry upheaval.

There seems to be a consensus that technological innovation is now more critical than ever to maintain the competitiveness of the oil and gas industry. According to Deloitte, “The industry is at a critical juncture where companies must go beyond merely acknowledging the need to innovate and start executing upon this imperative in a systematic way or else their long-term survival may be in jeopardy.” 1

TD 

At the same time, according to the Canadian Oil Sands Innovation Alliance (COSIA), when speaking to Canada’s standing committee on natural resources, “While some technologies are already in or nearing commercialization, many, especially the more transformative ones, could take more than a decade to become available for deployment. There is about a 10-year time horizon from ideation to commercial deployment in the oil and gas sector.” 2

How does the industry pursue innovation to drive real business value realization, find more innovative ways to cut costs, increase revenues, create more productive solutions in exploration and development, and make better decisions on operational risk — all while accelerating the pace to commercial deployment?

For starters, we work together. It sounds like a cliché but when key players, producers, research and technology innovators come together, the opportunity to vastly accelerate common industry agendas is realized. The healthcare industry is a perfect example of such transformative innovation through shared agendas.

Transformative technology like AI, advanced algorithms, machine-learning and cloud systems — powered by the IBM Watson platform — made its first impact in healthcare in 2012 starting with oncology — the study and treatment of cancer and tumors. Why healthcare? Two reasons: First, human health impacts us all, and second, the amount of data in the global healthcare industry is massive and AI systems like IBM Watson are built for big data challenges. Medical journals, clinical studies, medical text books, x-ray and scanning film, and personal healthcare records are full of important data, and the healthcare industry shares a common agenda — to deliver the best possible care to patients.

With this in mind, key healthcare organizations and IBM came together to build an oncology treatment advisor. Watson ingested millions of pieces of structured, unstructured and complex data — from both public and private sources — and dramatically changed the face of patient care. From there, IBM Watson and other industries joined forces to accelerate the pace of advancing common industry challenges within the banking and insurance, manufacturing, retail, education and yes, the oil and gas and mining industries, to drive real innovation across the value chain.

Secondly, when industry players work together on shared agendas, they also align current research, expertise and emergent technology solutions to existing challenges to accelerate immediate term profitability goals.

Notice we’re focusing on immediate term? We all know that when economic climates constrain, the focus rapidly turns to short-term performance as uncertainty drives up risk in longer-term innovation and capital project commitments.

Co-investment in shared industry programs delivers benefits almost impossible to reap as individual organizations, such as reduced project and development resources, reduced costs associated with common deployment environments, lower cost recovery thresholds and the benefit of higher reusability of program components and artifacts that reduces the need for redundant or new work efforts for each project initiation.

Thirdly, when industry players come together to form common agendas, they can more broadly capitalize on technological innovation and research such as the Internet of Things (IoT) and connected operations, predictive analytics, blockchain, cloud and AI. To be an innovator, you need to take risk, and with risk comes increased liability and the possibility of failure. According to the World Economic Forum, “the global oil and gas industry has at least 10 years to go before reaching a similar level of digital maturity to aerospace or automotive.”3

The natural resources industry has access to a tremendous amount of valuable data, technology and research capabilities. They are very good at collecting data, and the growth in data management service providers in the oil and gas industry supports this data collection; However, in the last five to ten years the growth in computing power and advanced technologies to capitalize and draw insight, understanding and predictions from historical data, and public data sources, has not been fully realized. The oil and gas industry still struggles with turning data into actionable insights that drive faster, safer and more intelligent work. The evolution of the industry from outdated legacy systems — not capable of handling the data and computer processing power available today — to more powerful operational focusses enabled digital systems will take time, effort, capital and most of all, a significant cultural change in the way the industry works and operates.

Imperative to the industry is the evolution to a modern operational architecture that can ingest the “4 V’s” of data — volume, variety, velocity and veracity — from internal and external sources, then integrate that insight into enterprise processes and workflows for meaningful outcomes. The advancement of AI platforms focused in specific industry verticals over the last five years, enables computing systems and AI to focus on simplifying the intensive processes and complexity in data collection and information retrieval, and even predictions, allowing the geologists and engineers to make better judgment calls and actions based on their experience and the new insights AI brings to their data sets.

Strategic enablement of digital technologies in the oil and gas industry is now fundamental to its survival. At IBM, we believe there is a place for shared agendas to advance innovation through digital transformation. We’ve just launched the IBM Watson for Natural Resources Innovation program in the Canadian oil and gas industry. This 4-year, thirty million dollar value creation program will advance business transformation and focus on a collaborative approach to reduce time-to-market and drive technology ROI.

Learn more about the Watson for Natural Resources Innovation Program through our live webinar on December 13

1Innovation in oil and gas Canada 2016, Monitor Deloitte, Doblin 2016.

2 The future of Canada’s oil and gas sector:  Innovation, sustainable solutions and economic opportunities. Report to standing committee on natural resources.  September 2016, 42nd Parliament, 1st Session.

3 World Economic Forum, January 2017

IBM Canada

IBM lives at the intersection of technology and business. As one of Canada’s top 10 private R&D investors, contributing more than $478 million to Canadian research activities, we are at the forefront of transformative technology and innovation. Our leading cloud-based AI platform is being used by businesses, developers, and universities around the world to fight cancer, improve classroom learning, minimize pollution, enhance agriculture and oil & gas exploration, better manage financial investments and much more.

The Natural Resources Solution Centre in Calgary is dedicated to clients’ in the Canadian oil and gas and mining industries. We are currently embarking on a 4-year thirty-million-dollar innovation program that focusses on performance, productivity and safety in the Canadian oil and gas industry.

Learn more about the Watson for Natural Resources Innovation Program through our live webinar on December 13


IN 
i951 : Health Care/Life Sciences

NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | nadvtr : Advertorials/Sponsored Content | ncat : Content Types

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020171208edc800009


SE Q&A; Exclusive
HD Energy researcher suggests safety emphasis for gas pipelines facing wary public
BY Ximena Mosqueda-Fernandez
WC 951 words
PD 5 December 2017
SN SNL Daily Gas Report
SC DGR
VOL Issue: 98407
LA English
CY Copyright 2017. SNL Financial LC

LP 

➤ Pipeline opponents' tactics have evolved, representing a broader audience and becoming more sophisticated.

➤ Midstream companies should highlight benefits of pipelines versus trains and natural gas versus coal.

TD 

➤ Getting social license "could be life or death for a certain pipeline."

Michael Webber, author and mechanical engineering professor at the University of Texas at Austin.

Source: University of Texas at Austin

Engineering professor Michael Webber is deputy director of the University of Texas at Austin's Energy Institute, where one of specialties is researching the intersection of energy infrastructure engineering and policy. S&P Global Market Intelligence talked with Webber about the challenges natural gas pipelines face in the current political, regulatory and market environment, as well as potential remedies for the industry. The following is an edited transcript of the conversation.

S&P Global Market Intelligence: There have been some recent decisions stalling or, in some instances, even overturning pipeline project approvals. Is this a sign that courts are becoming more sympathetic to pipeline opponents, or instead are pipeline opponents' arguments becoming more sophisticated?

Michael Webber: I don't think courts have changed their outlooks, necessarily. I do think the opponents have become more sophisticated in two ways. One, I think their coalitions are a little more diverse, so it's not just the environmental groups. They often bring in land-rights groups, and so they get a little more of an ideological spread that way. The other thing is they focus more of their effort on midstream rather than production sites. For a long time, opponents to oil and gas would focus on production to stop the extraction. Then they found over time that stopping the midstream is easier and it has the same effect because if you can't move gas to market, then you wouldn't produce in the first place.

The second piece to this is as time goes on, accidents happen. Every single accident of a pipeline, every spill or leak or problem, becomes part of the collection of evidence against pipelines. Time is on the side of the opponents. The more time goes on, the more accidents will happen, and that's used as part of the case to stop the construction of new pipes.

I think all projects are seeing the same kind of thing, which is more legal action at the midstream level, and more groups are brought to the table for that legal action. Every leak that happens just damns the case. The more leaks that happen, especially if it's the same company or pipeline or region, makes it that much harder to get approval.

Is there anything developers can do to counter this momentum that opponents seem to have?

I'm not sure what the best strategy is, but I think there are advantages if pipeline developers explain the relative safety of pipes versus trains. An alternative to moving by pipe is to move oil by train, for example, and trains have their own safety record that's problematic. They could talk about the comparative safety and cleanliness of the pipe versus the train.

The other thing they could talk about is the comparative safety of piped gas than coal, for example, because there's less pollution from gas and [fewer] people will die from respiratory infection. They've got the argument that pipelines actually offer an environmental advantage, compared to rail or coal. I think you'll start to see that kind of thing happen more and more.

What do midstream companies need to focus on in order to maintain their social license? Is that at risk in a post-Dakota Access and post-Keystone XL U.S.? If it is, how big of a risk factor are we talking about?

I think it is a risk. The midstream sector needs to do a better job developing stakeholder groups they can communicate well with and explain the broader argument of why it's beneficial to have pipelines. It's ultimately something pipeline companies have done a bad job on, that sort of social engagement, and that's how they get opposition. It could be life or death for a certain pipeline, not necessarily to the companies, but if they can't get a social license, they can't get a permit, they can't build or operate the pipeline. Absolutely, it's a high-stakes situation for them.

Looking out to 2018, what's the one area you think pipeline companies should focus on to ensure that a project will be successful?

Pipelines tend to be at their best when they are first built. Brand-new materials degrade over time because the soils shift or because of corrosion of the pipelines. The problem with pipelines is not year one, but maybe year 20, year 40 in its lifetime. One way to deal with that is to build in a fund that accumulates money so when the money is needed to improve or replace a pipeline, the money is available. It's easier to do that early on before you need it than to wait until you need it to do it. I feel like that should be part of what's going on with pipelines is built-in funding for when inevitably a problem occurs, to avoid that problem and then to mitigate that problem.

Is there anything else you want to mention that we have not covered?

The infrastructure of midstream, in general, is an important part of energy, not just for oil and gas and pipelines. Moving energy around is a difficult task and is required for all forms of energy.


CO 
unvtxa : University of Texas at Austin

NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News

RE 
usa : United States | austin : Austin | namz : North America | uss : Southern U.S. | ustx : Texas

IPD 
Gas Transportation

PUB 
SNL Financial LC

AN 
Document DGR0000020171206edc500005


HD Sponsored Content: Accelerate Oil And Gas Transformation With Advanced Technologies
WC 1236 words
PD 1 December 2017
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2017 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

The Canadian natural resources industry is undergoing enormous change. Volatile energy prices — the reality of US 55 per barrel — reduced production reliability, uncertain market access, the government’s climate change agenda, tightening environmental policy, safety, and compliance concerns along with increasing social drivers, such as social license to operate, all have resulted in industry upheaval.

There seems to be a consensus that technological innovation is now more critical than ever to maintain the competitiveness of the oil and gas industry. According to Deloitte, “The industry is at a critical juncture where companies must go beyond merely acknowledging the need to innovate and start executing upon this imperative in a systematic way or else their long-term survival may be in jeopardy.”1

TD 

At the same time, according to the Canadian Oil Sands Innovation Alliance (COSIA), when speaking to Canada’s standing committee on natural resources, “While some technologies are already in or nearing commercialization, many, especially the more transformative ones, could take more than a decade to become available for deployment. There is about a 10-year time horizon from ideation to commercial deployment in the oil and gas sector.” 2

How does the industry pursue innovation to drive real business value realization, find more innovative ways to cut costs, increase revenues, create more productive solutions in exploration and development, and make better decisions on operational risk — all while accelerating the pace to commercial deployment?

It sounds like a cliché but when key players, producers, research and technology innovators come together, the opportunity to vastly accelerate common industry agendas is realized. Two reasons: First, human health impacts us all, and second, the amount of data in the global healthcare industry is massive and AI systems like IBM Watson are built for big data challenges. Watson ingested millions of pieces of structured, unstructured and complex data — from both public and private sources — and dramatically changed the face of patient care. From there, IBM Watson and other industries joined forces to accelerate the pace of advancing common industry challenges within the banking and insurance, manufacturing, retail, education and yes, the oil and gas and mining industries, to drive real innovation across the value chain.

Secondly, when industry players work together on shared agendas, they also align current research, expertise and emergent technology solutions to existing challenges to accelerate immediate term profitability goals.

Notice we’re focusing on immediate term? We all know that when economic climates constrain, the focus rapidly turns to short-term performance as uncertainty drives up risk in longer-term innovation and capital project commitments.

Co-investment in shared industry programs delivers benefits almost impossible to reap as individual organizations, such as reduced project and development resources, reduced costs associated with common deployment environments, lower cost recovery thresholds and the benefit of higher reusability of program components and artifacts that reduces the need for redundant or new work efforts for each project initiation.

Thirdly, when industry players come together to form common agendas, they can more broadly capitalize on technological innovation and research such as the Internet of Things (IoT) and connected operations, predictive analytics, blockchain, cloud and AI. To be an innovator, you need to take risk, and with risk comes increased liability and the possibility of failure. According to the World Economic Forum, “the global oil and gas industry has at least 10 years to go before reaching a similar level of digital maturity to aerospace or automotive.”3

The natural resources industry has access to a tremendous amount of valuable data, technology and research capabilities. They are very good at collecting data, and the growth in data management service providers in the oil and gas industry supports this data collection; However, in the last five to ten years the growth in computing power and advanced technologies to capitalize and draw insight, understanding and predictions from historical data, and public data sources, has not been fully realized. The oil and gas industry still struggles with turning data into actionable insights that drive faster, safer and more intelligent work. The evolution of the industry from outdated legacy systems — not capable of handling the data and computer processing power available today — to more powerful operational focusses enabled digital systems will take time, effort, capital and most of all, a significant cultural change in the way the industry works and operates.

Imperative to the industry is the evolution to a modern operational architecture that can ingest the “4 V’s” of data — volume, variety, velocity and veracity — from internal and external sources, then integrate that insight into enterprise processes and workflows for meaningful outcomes. The advancement of AI platforms focused in specific industry verticals over the last five years, enables computing systems and AI to focus on simplifying the intensive processes and complexity in data collection and information retrieval, and even predictions, allowing the geologists and engineers to make better judgment calls and actions based on their experience and the new insights AI brings to their data sets.

Strategic enablement of digital technologies in the oil and gas industry is now fundamental to its survival. At IBM, we believe there is a place for shared agendas to advance innovation through digital transformation. We’ve just launched the IBM Watson for Natural Resources Innovation program in the Canadian oil and gas industry. This 4-year, thirty million dollar value creation program will advance business transformation and focus on a collaborative approach to reduce time-to-market and drive technology ROI.

Learn more about the Watson for Natural Resources Innovation Program through our live webinar on December 13

3 World Economic Forum, January 2017

IBM Canada

IBM lives at the intersection of technology and business. As one of Canada’s top 10 private R&D investors, contributing more than $478 million to Canadian research activities, we are at the forefront of transformative technology and innovation. Document DOILB00020171201edc10000c


HD Questerre Consolidates Antler Working Interest
WC 319 words
PD 27 November 2017
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2017 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

Questerre Energy Corporation says that it has closed an acquisition of producing Bakken/Torquay oil assets in the Antler area of southeast Saskatchewan.

The accretive acquisition consolidates the company’s operated working interest at Antler, Michael Binnion, president and chief executive officer of Questerre, said in a news release. “We now own 100 per cent of these assets and add low-decline, high netback light oil production to our base of conventional assets.”

TD 

Post the acquisition, current production from the area, including adjacent production from Pierson, Man., is approximately 450 bbl/d, he said.

Questerre acquired approximately 180 bbls/d of light oil production in the Antler area for gross consideration of $7.25 million, subject to customary industry adjustments. Acquired assets include 3D seismic data over the producing acreage with a value of approximately $770,000.

The effective date of the acquisition is Oct. 1, 2017. The company’s independent reserve engineers will evaluate the proved and probable reserves associated with the assets in conjunction with the year-end 2017 reserve evaluation.

Questerre also reported that it is submitting its comments on the draft hydrocarbon regulations to the ministry of Energy and Natural Resources in Quebec this week. The company said it anticipates that subject to the review of the comments received from stakeholders, the regulations should be finalized in early 2018.

Questerre said it is leveraging its expertise gained through early exposure to shale and other non-conventional reservoirs. It has base production and reserves in the tight oil Bakken/Torquay of southeast Saskatchewan and is bringing on production from its lands in the heart of the high-liquids Montney shale fairway.

The company said it is a leader on social license to operate issues for its Utica shale gas discovery in the St. Lawrence Lowlands, Que., and is pursuing oil shale projects with the aim of commercially developing these massive resources.

 


CO 
questc : Questerre Energy Corp

IN 
i1 : Energy | i13 : Crude Oil/Natural Gas Upstream Operations | iextra : Natural Gas/Oil Extraction

NS 
ccat : Corporate/Industrial News

RE 
cask : Saskatchewan | cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group

AN 
Document DOILB00020171127edbr0000a


HD Sponsored Content: Accelerate Oil And Gas Transformation With Advanced Technologies
WC 1236 words
PD 24 November 2017
SN The Daily Oil Bulletin
SC DOILB
LA English
CY (c)2017 copyright Junewarren-Nickle’s Energy Group. All rights reserved

LP 

The Canadian natural resources industry is undergoing enormous change. Volatile energy prices — the reality of US 55 per barrel — reduced production reliability, uncertain market access, the government’s climate change agenda, tightening environmental policy, safety, and compliance concerns along with increasing social drivers, such as social license to operate, all have resulted in industry upheaval.

TD

There is about a 10-year time horizon from ideation to commercial deployment in the oil and gas sector.” 2
